definition: A bright, lively quality in espresso flavor, often described as tartness or sharpness. Comes from organic acids in coffee. Distinct from bitterness.
A brewing device that uses air pressure to push water through coffee. Not technically espresso but sometimes used to approximate it.
The portafilter insert that holds the coffee puck. Available in single, double, and triple configurations, and in standard or precision/ridgeless variants.
The initial wetting of coffee grounds that causes CO2 to release, creating a bubbly 'bloom'. In espresso context, often called pre-infusion.
The physical weight and texture of the espresso on the palate — thin, medium, or full. Influenced by extraction, roast level, and emulsified oils.
A portafilter with the bottom removed, exposing the basket underside. Used to diagnose channeling and uneven extraction visually.
The ratio of dry coffee dose to liquid espresso output by weight (e.g., 1:2 means 18g in / 36g out). The single most important variable in espresso recipes.
The water temperature at the group head during extraction, typically 90–96°C (194–205°F). Higher temperatures extract more; lower temperatures extract less.
The grinding element in a grinder. Flat burrs and conical burrs produce different particle size distributions and flavor profiles.
The parallelism of the two burrs in a grinder. Misaligned burrs produce uneven particle sizes, hurting shot consistency.
A longer, less concentrated espresso drink (similar to lungo) popular in northern Europe. Also a term for crema itself in older literature.
The primary stimulant alkaloid in coffee. Espresso has less caffeine per volume than drip coffee but more per sip due to concentration.
The process of dialing in grind size, dose, and yield to hit a target recipe. Requires tasting and iteration.
An espresso drink with equal parts espresso, steamed milk, and milk foam, traditionally 150–180ml total.
When water finds a path of least resistance through the coffee puck rather than flowing evenly, resulting in over-extracted channels and under-extracted surrounding coffee.
A short espresso drink with an equal or near-equal ratio of espresso to steamed milk, typically 60–90ml total.
The reddish-brown foam on top of a freshly pulled espresso shot, formed by CO2 emulsified with oils. A marker of freshness and pressure, though not a reliable quality indicator.
The range of grind settings that produce similar results — fine adjustments within the dead zone don't meaningfully change extraction.
The process of CO2 escaping from roasted coffee over time. Fresh coffee degasses rapidly; too much CO2 causes inconsistent extraction.
The iterative process of adjusting variables (grind, dose, yield, time) to achieve a target shot. Every new bag of coffee requires dialing in.
How evenly coffee grounds are spread in the portafilter basket before tamping. Poor distribution leads to channeling.
The amount of dry ground coffee placed in the portafilter, measured by weight in grams. Typical espresso doses range from 14g to 22g.
Two shots of espresso, typically pulled from an 18–20g dose into ~36–40g output. The de facto standard in most specialty cafés.
A spent coffee puck that holds its shape and falls cleanly from the basket after extraction — sign of good dose and tamping.
A commercial grinder by Mahlkönig, widely regarded as producing exceptionally uniform particle size. Popularized in specialty espresso by Matt Perger.
A concentrated coffee beverage brewed by forcing pressurized hot water through finely ground coffee. Defined by high pressure (9 bar), fine grind, and short brew time.
The process of dissolving soluble compounds from coffee into water. Over-extraction tastes bitter/harsh; under-extraction tastes sour/weak.
The percentage of the dry coffee mass that dissolves into the brewed liquid. Specialty coffee targets ~18–22% for espresso.
Very small particles produced during grinding. Fines extract quickly and can clog channels, contributing to high resistance and channeling.
An audible cracking sound during coffee roasting when beans expand and internal pressure releases steam. Marks the beginning of light roast territory.
Disc-shaped grinding elements that grind coffee between two parallel flat surfaces. Known for clarity and brightness in flavor.
The speed at which water passes through the coffee puck, measured in ml/s. Controlled by grind size, dose, and pressure.
Running water through the group head briefly before pulling a shot to purge old water and stabilize temperature.
A kettle with a long curved spout for precision pouring. Primarily for pour-over but used by some for manual espresso devices.
The coarseness or fineness of ground coffee particles. Finer grind = more resistance = slower flow = more extraction. The primary adjustment variable.
The component on an espresso machine where the portafilter locks in and through which hot water is delivered to the coffee puck.
The gap between the top of the coffee puck and the shower screen in the group head. Affects pre-infusion behavior.
Heat exchanger espresso machine. Uses a single boiler with a heat exchanger tube for brew water, allowing simultaneous steam and brewing at different temperatures.
A coffee processing method where some or all fruit mucilage is left on the bean during drying. Produces fruity, syrupy characteristics.
The perceived strength or concentration of flavors in espresso. Not the same as extraction yield — a ristretto is intense but not necessarily well-extracted.
Lactic acid, found in some fermented/natural processed coffees. Contributes creamy, yogurt-like acidity.
An espresso drink with steamed milk and a thin layer of foam, typically 240–360ml. The most popular milk-based espresso drink.
Patterns created in the foam of steamed milk poured into espresso. Requires well-textured microfoam and a steady pour.
An espresso machine where the barista manually pulls a lever to generate extraction pressure, either directly or via a spring-loaded piston.
A long espresso shot with more water than a standard espresso, typically a 1:3–1:4 ratio. Tastes thinner but can reveal different flavor notes.
A chemical reaction between amino acids and sugars during roasting that creates hundreds of flavor compounds. Key to espresso's complexity.
Espresso 'stained' with a small amount of steamed milk or foam. Latte macchiato is the inverse — milk stained with espresso.
Silky, velvety steamed milk with tiny, uniform bubbles integrated throughout. Required for latte art and smooth milk-based drinks.
The tactile sensation of espresso in the mouth — viscosity, creaminess, dryness, or coating quality. Affected by oils, proteins, and brew ratio.
See 'bottomless portafilter.' The terms are interchangeable.
Coffee dried with the full fruit intact, imparting fruity, wine-like, or fermented flavors. Often challenging for espresso consistency.
A WDT technique where the needle moves in a circular or figure-8 pattern to break up clumps without over-aerating the grounds.
Over-Pressure Valve. A safety and calibration valve that limits maximum brew pressure. Often adjusted to 9 bar (or lower for 'low pressure profiling').
Where the coffee was grown. Single-origin espresso comes from one country or region; blends combine multiple origins for consistency.
When too many compounds are dissolved from the coffee, producing bitter, harsh, astringent, or empty flavors.
How densely coffee is compressed in the basket. Over-packing (too much tamp pressure) and under-packing can both cause problems.
The spread of different grind sizes produced by a grinder. Narrower PSD = more uniform extraction. Burr quality heavily influences PSD.
Slang for the flat raised ring on some portafilter baskets that prevents the puck from sticking. Also called a 'lip' or 'ridge'.
Water passing through a bed of coffee grounds. Espresso is a form of pressurized percolation.
The cylinder component in lever machines that applies force to generate brew pressure.
The handle-and-basket assembly that clips into the group head. Holds the coffee puck during extraction.
A low-pressure or no-pressure initial wetting of the puck before full pressure is applied. Reduces channeling and improves even extraction.
The force applied to water during extraction, measured in bar. Standard espresso uses ~9 bar; some modern approaches use lower pressure.
Dynamically changing brew pressure during extraction to influence flavor. Enabled by machines with programmable pressure curves.
The compressed disc of spent coffee grounds after extraction. Should be firm, dry, and hold its shape.
Colloquial term for brewing a shot of espresso (from the lever-pulling motion of early machines).
Running steam or water through the machine to clear old coffee residue or stabilize temperature.
A 'restricted' espresso shot using less water than a standard double, typically a 1:1 ratio. Syrupy, intense, and often sweeter.
The date the coffee was roasted. Espresso typically performs best 7–21 days post-roast, after initial CO2 degassing.
How darkly the coffee was roasted: light, medium, or dark. Light roasts favor acidity and origin character; dark roasts favor bitterness and body.
A digital scale used to measure dose and yield precisely. Essential for recipe consistency. Espresso-specific scales measure in 0.1g increments.
A portafilter-mounted thermocouple tool for measuring actual brew temperature at the group head. Used for machine calibration.
The duration of the espresso extraction from first drop to target yield. Typically 25–35 seconds for a standard double.
An espresso machine with one boiler used for both brewing and steaming. Requires temperature surfing or waiting between tasks.
Coffee from one specific country, region, farm, or lot. Often used to highlight unique terroir flavors rather than blend consistency.
A pre-infusion technique that uses slow, low-flow pre-infusion for an extended period before ramping to full pressure. Named after Slayer espresso machines.
An electrically controlled valve in the group head that releases back-pressure when the shot ends, allowing the puck to depressurize.
The density of brewed espresso relative to water. Can be used to estimate TDS without a refractometer.
Barista slang for espresso.
Coffee that has lost its aromatic volatile compounds, typically from oxygen exposure or being too far past roast date. Produces flat, papery espresso.
The metal tube on an espresso machine that delivers high-pressure steam for frothing and heating milk.
The initial phase of milk steaming where air is incorporated to increase volume. Done by keeping the wand tip near the milk surface.
A technique on single-boiler machines where the barista times the shot to hit a stable brew temperature window.
A flat-bottomed tool used to compress coffee grounds in the portafilter basket. Typically 58mm for standard group heads.
Applying even, downward pressure to the coffee grounds in the portafilter using a tamper. Creates uniform resistance for water flow.
A measurement of dissolved material in brewed coffee, expressed as a percentage. Used with extraction yield to calibrate espresso strength.
A coffee movement emphasizing quality, traceability, and brewing science. Associated with light roasts, single origins, and espresso precision.
Scorching of coffee bean tips during roasting, caused by too-high drum temperature. Can contribute to harsh flavors.
A high-yield, fast espresso shot (often 1:3.5–1:5 ratio in under 15 seconds) achieved with a coarser grind. Developed by researchers including Jonathan Gagné.
When too few compounds are dissolved from the coffee, producing sour, grassy, salty, or watery flavors.
Using more coffee than a basket's rated capacity to increase resistance and body. Common workaround for coarser grind limitations.
Negative pressure in the group head after the solenoid releases, which helps pull back water from the puck.
The silky texture of well-steamed microfoam milk. Well-velveted milk pours cleanly and integrates smoothly with espresso.
Measuring espresso output by volume (ml) rather than weight. Less precise than gravimetric dosing due to crema variability.
Precision portafilter baskets made by VST (Vince Fedele's company) with tightly controlled hole geometry for more even extraction.
The mineral content of water, measured in ppm or °dH. Affects scale buildup in machines and can influence extraction and flavor.
A method of stirring coffee grounds in the basket with a thin needle tool to break up clumps and improve distribution before tamping.
Washed coffee processing method. Produces cleaner, brighter flavors with more consistent extractions.
The weight of liquid espresso in the cup, measured in grams. Along with dose, defines the brew ratio.
